heat - a) the quality of being hot; hotness; b) (phys.) a form of energy existing as the result of the random motion of molecules and transferred between bodies as a result of their temperature difference.
a sharp, active man.
much hotness; great warmth (as in the atmosphere).
the warmest season of the year; summer.
ಉಷ್ಣದ ಯಾಂತ್ರಿಕ ಸಾಮ್ಯ uṣṇada yāntrika sāmya the conversion factor between heat energy and mechanical energy; mechanical equivalent of heat.
that which heats; an apparatus for heating a room or building; a heater.
decomposition of a substance by heat; pyrolysis.
a disease of the eye characterised by redness and inflammation.
the branch of physics dealing with the transformation of heat to and from other forms of energy, and with the laws governing such conversions of energy; thermodynamics.
thermodynamic - a) of or having to do with thermodynamics; b) caused or operated by heat converted into motive power.
the action in which the resultant objects absorb the heat produced; endothermic action.
that which absorbs heat.
any action at the end of which heat is given out; exothermic action.
produced by heat.
the development of electric dipoles in certain crystalline materials as a result of temperature changes; pyro-electricity.
hot water.
any of various diseases characterised by a high temperature.

a serious failure of the body's heat-regulation mechanisms resulting from excessive exposure to intense heat and characterised by high fever, dry skin, collapse, and sometimes convulsions or coma; heat-stroke.
the gradual rising of temperature with the depth into the earth; temperature gradient.

temperature - the degree of hotness or coldness of anything, usu. as measured on a thermometer; as - a) the degree of heat of a living body; b) an excess of this over the normal (about 98.60 F or 370 C in humans); fever; c) the degree of heat of the atmosphere; d) the degree of heat of anything.
producing heat; calorific.
the amount of heat produced by a specified quantity of fuel, food, etc.; calorific value.
the transmutation of heat rays into luminous rays; calorescence.
the transfer of heat by its absorption by a fluid at one point followed by motion of the fluid and rejection of the heat at another point; convection.
a disease of the eye characterised by redness and inflammation.
an apparatus for regulating temperature, esp. one that automatically controls a heating or cooling unit; a thermostat.
= ಉಷ್ಣವಲಯ.
the act of radiating or emitting rays, esp. the emission of heat, light etc. in the form of electromagnetic waves or particles; radiation.
the sun, whose rays of light are scorching.
a measuring of temperature; the degree of hotness (as measured with a thermometer).
